title: FK Radnički Niš
text:
Fudbalski klub Radnički (), commonly known as Radnički Niš (), is a professional <a href="football%20club">football club</a> based in <a href="Ni%C5%A1">Niš</a>, Serbia. Its name means "Labourers" in <a href="Serbian%20language">Serbian</a> and stems from the relationship with the <a href="Labour%20movement">Labour movement</a> which the club had during the first half of the 20th century.
Radnički Niš was one of the most stable clubs in the former <a href="SFR%20Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>. The team spent a total of 29 seasons in the <a href="Yugoslav%20First%20League">Yugoslav First League</a>, achieved two 3rd-place finishes in <a href="1979%E2%80%9380%20Yugoslav%20First%20League">1980</a> and <a href="1980%E2%80%9381%20Yugoslav%20First%20League">1981</a>, and one 3rd-place finish in <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Serbian%20SuperLiga">2018</a>. In international competition, Radnički Niš won the <a href="Balkans%20Cup">1975 Balkans Cup</a>, reached the final in <a href="Balkans%20Cup">1989</a>, and played against <a href="Hamburger%20SV">Hamburger SV</a> in the semi-finals of the <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a> in <a href="1981%E2%80%9382%20UEFA%20Cup">1982</a>.
History.
Beginnings (1923–1945).
The club was founded on April 24, 1923, in the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Serbs%2C%20Croats%20and%20Slovenes">Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes</a>. One of its founders was the communist activist Miloš Marković (who also founded <a href="Sloboda%20U%C5%BEice">Sloboda Užice</a> in 1925). In the same year, the club played its first unofficial matches. Two years later, in the 1925–26 season, the club became part of the professional league of the <a href="Morava%20Banovina">Morava Banovina</a>, and won the championship on two occasions, in the 1924–25 and 1927–28 seasons. Following the proclamation of the royal dictatorship in 1929, the government began to persecute leftist activists, and Radnički changed its name to Građanski. As Građanski Niš, the club played in the <a href="1935%E2%80%9336%20Yugoslav%20Football%20Championship">1935–36 Yugoslav Football Championship</a> which was played in a straight-knockout competition format, and was eliminated in the round of sixteen by <a href="Gragjanski%20Skopje">Građanski Skoplje</a>. At the end of that season the club reinstated its original name, and played until 1941, when, because of the war, the club ceased its activities and its members and players joined the resistance.
At the beginning of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> in the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Yugoslavia">Kingdom of Yugoslavia</a> in 1941, the club terminated the activities, which were renewed in 1945, one year after the liberation from the occupation of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>.
The rise and stabilization (1962–1975).
In <a href="1962%E2%80%9363%20Yugoslav%20First%20League">1962</a>, Radnički Niš were promoted to the <a href="Yugoslav%20First%20League">Yugoslav First League</a> for the first time in the club's history. On 23 September 1962, Radnički fans displayed their first big choreography on the first league match against <a href="Red%20Star%20Belgrade">Red Star Belgrade</a>. A large banner reading "Real sa Nišave", which translates to "<a href="Real%20Madrid">Real</a> from <a href="Nisava">Nisava</a>" was raised on the east stand, and the club bears this nickname to this day. The banner could be seen at every home game throughout the 1960s. In following years, the club underwent major development and became one of the most stable football clubs in the country. In 1963, the club founded its youth school, through which many of the Radnički players passed. In 1975, Radnički beat Turkish club <a href="Eski%C5%9Fehirspor">Eskişehirspor</a> (1–0, 2–1) and won its first trophy of European importance, the <a href="Balkans%20Cup">Balkans Cup</a>.
The Golden Era (1980–1984).
In <a href="1979%E2%80%9380%20Yugoslav%20First%20League">1980</a>, Radnički finished the national championship in 3rd place, the best placement thus far, and played for the first time in the <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a> in the following season, during which Radnički reached the round of sixteen, but lost against Dutch club <a href="AZ%20Alkmaar">AZ Alkmaar</a>. In <a href="1980%E2%80%9381%20Yugoslav%20First%20League">1981</a>, the club was again third and qualified for the <a href="1981%E2%80%9382%20UEFA%20Cup">1981–82 UEFA Cup</a> season. In the first round, Radnički Niš were drawn against <a href="S.S.C.%20Napoli">Napoli</a>. In the first leg, the club from South Serbia achieved a 2–2 draw in front of 70.000 spectators at <a href="Stadio%20San%20Paolo">Stadio San Paolo</a>, which was enough for Radnički to progress after a goalless match in <a href="Serbia">Serbia</a> because of the away goals rule. After eliminating "the Azzurri", Radnički played the second round against <a href="Grasshopper%20Club%20Z%C3%BCrich">Grasshopper Club Zürich</a>. The Swiss club won the first match in Zürich by 2–0, but Radnički had equalized with a 2–0 and won convincingly 3–0 in the penalty shoot-out. In the third round, the club played against <a href="Feyenoord">Feyenoord</a> from Rotterdam. In the first leg in <a href="Ni%C5%A1">Niš</a>, the result was 2–0 for Radnički and at "De Kuip" the result was 1–0 for the Dutch club. However, it was a 2–1 victory on aggregate for the Serbian club and in the quarter-finals Radnički were drawn against <a href="Dundee%20United%20F.C.">Dundee United</a> from Scotland. In the first leg, played in Dundee, Radnički suffered a 2–0 defeat. Although they were not seen as the favourites in the return leg, the "Real from Nišava" pulled off a convincing 3–0 win in front of its spectators, and with an aggregate score of 3–2 they eventually achieved their greatest success by reaching the semi-finals of this prestigious tournament. The semi-finals provided a football holiday at <a href="%C4%8Cair%20Stadium">Čair Stadium</a>, due to the fact that German top club <a href="Hamburger%20SV">Hamburger SV</a>, led by stars like <a href="Horst%20Hrubesch">Horst Hrubesch</a>, <a href="Felix%20Magath">Felix Magath</a>, <a href="Lars%20Bastrup">Lars Bastrup</a>, <a href="Manfred%20Kaltz">Manfred Kaltz</a>, <a href="Thomas%20von%20Heesen">Thomas von Heesen</a> and <a href="Uli%20Stein">Uli Stein</a> would play in <a href="Ni%C5%A1">Niš</a>. In the first leg, Radnički Niš won against the favored North Germans in front of 38,500 enthusiastic Radnički fans with 2–1, but they lost the second leg in Hamburg by 5–1 (Hamburg lost at the end the final, but won next year the <a href="1982%E2%80%9383%20European%20Cup">1982–83 European Cup</a>). After one year of absence from international football, the club qualified for the <a href="1983%E2%80%9384%20UEFA%20Cup">1983–84 UEFA Cup</a> season (finished the <a href="1979%E2%80%9380%20Yugoslav%20First%20League">1979–80 Yugoslav First League</a> season in 4th place) and reached the round of sixteen, as in <a href="1980%E2%80%9381%20UEFA%20Cup">1981</a>. After winning matches against <a href="FC%20St.%20Gallen">St Gallen</a> (3–0, 2–1) and <a href="FK%20Inter%20Bratislava">FK Inter Bratislava</a> (4–0, 2–3), Radnički played against <a href="Hajduk%20Split">Hajduk Split</a>. It was the first intra-Yugoslav fixture in UEFA cup. Hajduk won both matches 2–0 and progressed to the quarter-finals.
Radnički Niš played a total of 22 matches across Europe between 1981 and 1984. During this time, Radnički lost only one <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a> home match of a total of 11 across three seasons and only against a team from the domestic league. A major contribution was made by the fans and their enthusiastic support. The <a href="%C4%8Cair%20Stadium">Čair Stadium</a> was a tough ground for the opposition and the atmosphere created by Radnički fans in a roaring stadium always gave hope to the team that they could overcome anybody.
Late Yugoslavia period/Serbia-Montenegro period (1985–2006).
After the golden years, Radnički Niš was unexpectedly relegated to in the <a href="Yugoslav%20Second%20League">Yugoslav Second League</a> in 1985, after 23 continuous years in the first league. However, under coach <a href="Josip%20Duvan%C4%8Di%C4%87">Josip Duvančić</a>, Radnički won the <a href="Yugoslav%20Second%20League">Yugoslav Second League</a> in the following season and returned to the first league after only a year of absence. In 1989, the club played its second <a href="Balkans%20Cup">Balkans Cup</a> final after 1975, but they lost against <a href="OFI%20Crete%20F.C.">OFI Crete</a> of Greece by 3–1. At the beginning of the 1990s, the entire country was plunged into a crisis. The disintegration of Yugoslavia, the civil war (1992–95), the inflation and the UN sanctions hit all the Yugoslav football teams hard, and also Radnički was no exception. In the 2000–01 season, the club dropped out of the first division for the second time in its history. In the following season, Radnički Niš won the second division championship and quickly returned to the major clubs, but they ended the 2002–03 season in last place. After that, the club competed in the second league for the following five seasons.
Serbian SuperLiga.
In the 2008–09 season, Radnički was even relegated to Serbia's <a href="Serbian%20League">third division</a>. They won the division, but they ended the <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20Serbian%20First%20League">2009–10 Serbian First League</a> season in the relegation zone. In the 2010–11 season, they won the <a href="Serbian%20League%20East">Serbian League East</a> and were promoted to the <a href="Serbian%20First%20League">Serbian First League</a>, <a href="Serbian%20football%20league%20system">Serbia's second division</a>. What followed was a consecutive promotion. The club won the <a href="2011-12%20Serbian%20First%20League">2011-12 Serbian First League</a> and was promoted to the <a href="Serbian%20SuperLiga">Serbian SuperLiga</a>, Serbia's highest football tier. In the same season, the club's home ground was rebuilt, which rekindled the fans' hopes further. Since then club become stable in Serbian SuperLiga gradually improving its position on the league table and establish itself as a major club in Serbian football once again. First season in highest division Radnički Niš finished in 12th place but kept improving every following season, finishing 6th, 9th and twice in 5th place. In season <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Serbian%20SuperLiga">2017–18 Serbian SuperLiga</a> Radnički Niš finished in third place, which guaranteed them place in first qualifying round of <a href="UEFA%20Europa%20League">UEFA Europa League</a>. The following season marked the club's return to European competitions where they eliminated Maltese club <a href="Gzira%20United">Gzira United</a> 5–0 on aggregate in the first qualifying round for the <a href="2018-19%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">2018-19 UEFA Europa League</a>. Radnički was later eliminated in the second round by the favoured Israeli team <a href="Maccabi%20Tel%20Aviv%20F.C.">Maccabi Tel Aviv</a> 4–2 on aggregate. In the <a href="2018-19%20Serbian%20SuperLiga">SuperLiga</a>, Radnički finished the season in second place behind defending champions <a href="Red%20Star%20Belgrade">Red Star Belgrade</a>, once again reaching the qualifying rounds for the UEFA Europa League.
Club colors and crest.
The club performed in a green-white jersey and on the left, in the white field, was a red five-pointed star as a symbol of affiliation with the <a href="Labour%20movement">Labour movement</a>, the colour of which was later taken as a frequent kit color of Radnički. The club also used a blue and white kit, which was commonly seen during promotion play-offs and international fixtures, so the club bears all the colors of the <a href="Flag%20of%20Serbia">Serbian flag</a>. The crest is in the colors red and white, and bears the inscription of the year of foundation and the image of the <a href="Ni%C5%A1%20Fortress">Niš Fortress</a>, which is a complex and important cultural and historical monument of the city of <a href="Ni%C5%A1">Niš</a>.
Kit evolution 
 
Stadium.
The home ground of Radnički Niš is the <a href="%C4%8Cair%20Stadium">Čair Stadium</a>. It is named after the Čair neighbourhood in <a href="Medijana">Medijana</a>, the most populous municipality of <a href="Ni%C5%A1">Niš</a>. The construction of the stadium was finished in 1963, and had a capacity of 40,000 spectators. After renovations between 2011 and 2012, the stadium capacity has been brought to 18,151 seats. The stadium is part of the Čair sports complex, which also includes the modern sporting arena <a href="%C4%8Cair%20Sports%20Center">Čair</a>, a modern indoor swimming pool and other facilities. After the renovation of the swimming pool, the Čair Sports Center, and the complete reconstruction of the Čair stadium, <a href="Ni%C5%A1">Niš</a> was endowed with a unique sports complex in Serbia and completed a full reconstruction of its sports infrastructure.
Reconstruction.
The Čair stadium began undergoing complete reconstruction during the second half of 2011 in an ambitious project by the <a href="Football%20Association%20of%20Serbia">Football Association of Serbia</a> and the city of <a href="Ni%C5%A1">Niš</a>. The project included the renovation of eastern, southern and northern stands. When reconstruction was finished, the stadium's seating capacity had been increased to 18,151 spectators, including an additional VIP lounge with 120 seats and a media lodge with 50 seats. The project also entailed covering the whole stadium, new <a href="Floodlights%20%28sport%29">floodlights</a> and <a href="LED%20display">LED</a>, a new locker room and press room, new infirmaries, a parking area, ticket offices, a restaurant and a TV room for broadcasts. After reconstruction, the stadium fulfilled the most up to date <a href="UEFA">UEFA</a> standards. The cost of the project was estimated to be over 1.1 billion Serbian <a href="dinar">dinar</a>s (10 million <a href="euro">euro</a>s).
Debut game at the new stadium.
Although it had not been completely finished, <a href="%C4%8Cair%20Stadium">Čair Stadium</a> was declared as a suitable venue for the second home match (first home match had to be played at <a href="Stadion%20FK%20Jagodina">Jagodina City Stadium</a> against <a href="FK%20Radni%C4%8Dki%201923">Radnički Kragujevac</a>). However, the home opening match took place in the 5th round of Serbian SuperLiga against <a href="FK%20Smederevo%201924">Smederevo 1924</a> on September 15, 2012. About 7,000 seats had been initially installed and they were completely filled as Radnički Niš has hosted its first SuperLiga match after 9 years. Manager <a href="Aleksandar%20Ili%C4%87%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201969%29">Aleksandar Ilić</a> fielded the following squad: <a href="Stevan%20Stefanovi%C4%87">Stevan Stefanović</a>, <a href="Branislav%20Vukomanovi%C4%87">Branislav Vukomanović</a>, <a href="Milan%20Jovanovi%C4%87%20%28Serbian%20footballer%20born%201983%29">Milan Jovanović</a>, <a href="Marko%20Ran%C4%91elovi%C4%87">Marko Ranđelović</a>, <a href="Milo%C5%A1%20Peri%C4%87">Miloš Perić</a>, <a href="Bratislav%20Pej%C4%8Di%C4%87">Bratislav Pejčić</a>, <a href="Aleksandar%20Jovanovi%C4%87%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201985%29">Aleksandar Jovanović</a>, <a href="Du%C5%A1an%20Kolarevi%C4%87">Dušan Kolarević</a>, <a href="Milo%C5%A1%20Petrovi%C4%87">Miloš Petrović</a>, <a href="Vladan%20Bini%C4%87">Vladan Binić</a> and <a href="Strahinja%20Petrovi%C4%87">Strahinja Petrović</a>. Radnički supporters had to wait till the 84th minute when midfielder Dušan Kolarević scored via a 30-meter strike and brought Radnički Niš to a 1–0 win in the opening match.
Radnički's Ivan Krstić youth school.
An important segment of the club is its youth school, which was founded in 1963, through which many of the Radnički players passed. The youth school is named after former Radnički's football player <a href="Ivan%20%26quot%3BBeli%26quot%3B%20Krsti%C4%87">Ivan Krstić</a>. He enrolled in Radnički's youth school at the age of and settled in the first team and became captain. At the threshold of a great football career, he lost his life during training as a result of a lightning strike on the auxiliary field, near the youth school. In memory of the tragically lost star player, the football schools bears his name to this day.
History.
During 1963, one year after entry of Radnički in the <a href="Yugoslav%20First%20League">Yugoslav First League</a>, the club formed its own football schools at the initiative of Tihomir Petrović. Forty-eight players were selected from nine primary schools and began to learn the football alphabet at Radnički. It was a bright start to the football school tradition of Radnički which would eventually become a real talent pool, producing many football names that would spread the word about Niš, Yugoslav and Serbian football. The first greater success came in 1966, when they won a large tournament in Germany. In 1969, this was followed by winning a tournament in Paris, defeating the Italian team US Cagliari. More success followed and one of the highlights was the win at the international tournament "<a href="FK%20Vojvodina">Vojvodina</a>-<a href="Red%20Star%20Belgrade">Red Star</a>", which was played in 1984 and which saw the participation of many national and international top youth teams. During the tournament, Radnički's youth was led by <a href="Milorad%20Jankovi%C4%87">Milorad Janković</a>, a former player of Radnički, who was honoured as the top youth coach by the <a href="Football%20Association%20of%20Yugoslavia">Football Association of Yugoslavia</a>. 1991 will be remembered as the year when Radnički's youth achieved their greatest success. For the first time, led by coach Vladislav Nikolić, they won the Yugoslav championship, after defeating <a href="FK%20%C5%BDeljezni%C4%8Dar%20Sarajevo">Željezničar Sarajevo</a> (1–0 at home by a goal from <a href="Dejan%20Petkovi%C4%87">Dejan Petković</a>, 1–1). In 1992, Radnički again fielded a national championship team in their series. Its cadets were Yugoslav champions and repeated the success achieved the previous year, which was a triumph for the managers of the youth school and coaches like Miroslav Glišović, <a href="Milorad%20Jankovi%C4%87">Milorad Janković</a>, <a href="Ljubi%C5%A1a%20Rajkovi%C4%87">Ljubiša Rajković</a> and Miodrag Stefanović. In that period, Radnički's football school was well known for its youth work, which demonstrated a high level of technical skill, especially recognizable in young players such as <a href="Dragan%20Stojkovi%C4%87">Dragan Stojković</a> and <a href="Dejan%20Petkovi%C4%87">Dejan Petković</a>, as well as tactical readiness in combination with adaptability. The last major success of the Radnički's football school was in 2000, when Radnički's cadets, led by coach Aleksandar Jovanovski, won the Serbian championship. In the final, they beat <a href="Red%20Star%20Belgrade">Red Star Belgrade</a> by 1–0 and qualified for the final tournament for the Yugoslav championship. In the contest for the best cadet teams in the country, Radnički's young players achieved the 3rd place. In the same year, new sport facilities were opened which facilitated better working conditions. Today, the youth coaches are mostly former players of Radnički who are responsible for 400–450 young Radnički players and working according to the standards of major European football clubs.
Supporters.
The first large organized support happened in 1962 against Vardar, when several thousand fans from <a href="Ni%C5%A1">Niš</a> travelled to <a href="Skoplje">Skoplje</a>. In 1962, Radnički Niš were promoted to the <a href="Yugoslav%20First%20League">Yugoslav First League</a> for the first time in their history and attracted more supporters from Niš and the surrounding region. Since Radnički's entry to the first division, <a href="%C4%8Cair%20Stadium">Čair</a> has always been a tough ground for the opposition. Although the club has had numerous supporters throughout the history, more organized groups emerged at the end of the 1980s. The name Meraklije was accepted, which roughly translates to "bohemian hedonists". The name has been synonymous with region customs for centuries.
Besides the football club, Meraklije also support other sport sections like <a href="Team%20handball">handball</a>, and the <a href="Serbia%20men%27s%20national%20handball%20team">Serbian national handball team</a>.

Since 2000, Radnički Niš have not issued the squad number 10. It was <a href="Retired%20numbers%20in%20association%20football">retired</a> in memory of <a href="Ivan%20Krsti%C4%87%20%28footballer%29">Ivan Krstić</a>, who was killed by lightning on 29 May 2000 on the training match. His son will be able to wear number 10 in the future.
